Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/Ambari-Github-PullRequest-Builder/864/
Test PASSed.

I am not sure if his change is appropriate.  There are several places where `jceks://` is expected. So changing that one line seems like a problem waiting to happen.  

I think we need to look more closely at the use case and design a more robust solution.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/Ambari-Github-PullRequest-Builder/865/
Test FAILed.
Test FAILured.
@rlevas @adoroszlai @zeroflag @dlysnichenko Please review this PR. Thanks!

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/Ambari-Github-PullRequest-Builder/866/
Test FAILed.
Test FAILured.

I see. I saw, that it assumes 3 lines earlier, that the URL starts with 'jceks://file', so I assumed that Ambari only worked with local files, so no harm could be  and as this localjceks provider is in hadoop since 2.6.x, I thought, all of the relevant component has support for it.
 However, we can make this change opt-in, only for Oozie. 

What do you think?
@atkach OK, I have addressed your comments.

@gzsombor , I like this newer approach better. But is it still unclear to me what changed in Oozie that requires this.

Does the following block need to be changed too?

`common-services/OOZIE/4.0.0.2.0/package/scripts/oozie.py:328`
```
      hive_site_config = update_credential_provider_path(params.config['configurations']['hive-site'],
                                                         'hive-site',
                                                         os.path.join(params.hive_conf_dir, 'hive-site.jceks'),
                                                         params.oozie_user,
                                                         params.user_group
                                                         )
```

Sorry, I may be doing something wrong here. I just intended to merge the last commit (AMBARI-22999) in this list. 
It automatically shows the first one AMBARI-22833, which I had committed before. 
Also it shows the 2 merge commits in between. 
Let me know if there is something I need to do here.

https://builds.apache.org/job/Ambari-Github-PullRequest-Builder/922/
Test FAILed.
Test FAILured.

> AMBARI-22945. Enhance host components API to support multiple host co  

Adds/changes the following:

1. Fixes the failing UTs

2. Cleans up the code changes made around AMS controller code. We will be as of now continue to pass String value as component Name. Ams code needs to be enhanced to uniquely identify a given component instance using SG name, Service Name and Component Name, as they can't use id.

3. UI code changes to pass in service_group_name and service_name while doing **POST** for **HOST Component**(s).

Manual testing done as follows:

1. Installed cluster for HDFS and ZK with new bits. Works.
2. Tested Host API bulk operation, details here : https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMBARI-22945?focusedCommentId=16383438&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-16383438

> AMBARI-22945. Enhance host components API to support multiple host co

- Updated ''AmbariManagementControllerTest.java' after merge.
retest this please

@nitirajrathore , The diff looks ok. So when we merge, we should choose Squash and Merge to squash the patches into one merge.

Scott, I don't think this pull request is correct - it contains a ton of other commits in it. Perhaps when you tried to update your pull request branch, you didn't stash and then re-apply your commits?
